7 things you‚Äôre NOT responsible for at work:

(It‚Äôs costing you more than you realize.)

Too many high-achievers carry weight that isn‚Äôt theirs.

They overextend. Overcommit. Over-own.

But being a good colleague doesn‚Äôt mean taking on everyone‚Äôs burdens.

Here are 7 things you need to stop taking responsibility for:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Other people‚Äôs growth

‚Ü≥ You can offer support, but you can‚Äôt do the work for them.
‚Ü≥ Their progress isn‚Äôt your burden.
‚Ü≥ Their timeline is their own.

2Ô∏è‚É£ A toxic workplace culture

‚Ü≥ You can set a good example, but you can‚Äôt fix it alone.
‚Ü≥ A broken system isn‚Äôt yours to carry.
‚Ü≥ Protect your energy instead of fighting uphill battles.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Everyone‚Äôs emotional comfort

‚Ü≥ You can be kind without absorbing their stress.
‚Ü≥ Their reactions are not your responsibility.
‚Ü≥ If your success triggers them, let it.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Cleaning up inherited chaos

‚Ü≥ You didn‚Äôt create the mess.
‚Ü≥ You‚Äôre not here to fix the past.
‚Ü≥ Set boundaries and move forward.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Other people‚Äôs expectations

‚Ü≥ Their version of you isn‚Äôt your problem.
‚Ü≥ You don‚Äôt owe anyone your potential.
‚Ü≥ Their disappointment is theirs to manage.

6Ô∏è‚É£ Colleagues‚Äô motivation

‚Ü≥ You can encourage, but you can‚Äôt force drive.
‚Ü≥ Their work ethic is their responsibility.
‚Ü≥ You‚Äôre not responsible for carrying their slack.

7Ô∏è‚É£ Perfection in every task

‚Ü≥ Excellence isn‚Äôt perfection.
‚Ü≥ Progress matters more than flawlessness.
‚Ü≥ Mistakes don‚Äôt define you, learning from them does.

The most freeing thing you can do?

Let go of what‚Äôs weighing you down.

Work lighter.
Live better.

And focus on what actually matters.

- - -

P.S. Which one are you letting go of first?

postsData.name:
Omar Halabieh
Omar Halabieh
postsData.content:
Your potential means nothing without discipline, 

And most people don't have it because they're addicted to comfort ‚Äî including me, until I got fed up with my own excuses.

Here's what actually worked for me (stripped of the motivational BS):

1/ Start Microscopic

Most people fail because they try to become Navy SEALs overnight.

Your grandiose plans are killing your progress.

I learned this the hard way - I used to write elaborate morning routines that looked great on paper but failed miserably in practice.

Start so small it feels like a joke. One pushup. Two minutes of meditation.

Your ego will hate it. Good. That's the point.

2/ Your Environment Is Making You Weak

Hard truth: Willpower is overrated.

If you need willpower to resist something, you've already lost.

I had to remove most of the junk food at home before I finally started eating healthy.

Stop testing your discipline against unnecessary temptations.

3/ Habit Stacking Works

Don't create new routines - hijack existing ones.

I failed for years trying to 'find time' to learn new things.

Then I made one simple change: No walking without a podcast.

Now I learn for 45 minutes daily because my back pain from sitting is more reliable than my motivation will ever be.

Stop fighting your existing habits. Exploit them instead.

4/ The Discomfort Principle

Here's what nobody tells you: If you're too comfortable, you're losing.

Every day you avoid discomfort, someone else is embracing it and getting stronger.

This isn't about motivation - it's about being fed up with mediocrity.

1.5 yeas ago, I started posting videos on LinkedIn.

First video? 31 takes, shaking hands, nervous sweat. Looked like a hostage video. Posted it anyway.

Comments were brutal. One guy told me to look straight at the camera (duh!).

Now? Not only has my content reached millions, but my entire relationship with discomfort changed. The thing that scared me most became my biggest asset.

5/ Energy Management Beats Time Management

I am not part of the 5 AM club, nor do I care when you wake up.

What matters is how you use your peak energy hours.

Find yours and protect them violently.

Mine are 8 AM to 12 PM.

6/ Identity Is Everything

Most discipline advice focuses on actions.

But here's the reality: Actions follow identity.

A disciplined person isn't someone who occasionally does disciplined things.

They embody discipline in everything.

Start with who you want to be.

I stopped saying 'I'm trying to be more productive' and started saying 'I'm a high-performer.'

Identity decides before the temptation arrives.


These insights are inspired by 'The Power of Discipline' by Daniel Walter and brought to you by Omar's Desk.

What's one micro-habit you will start this week?

PS: Discipline isn't about perfection - it's about consistency.

Image Credit: Quotefancy

Ô∏è Repost to help others turn their dreams into reality through discipline.
 Followfor more.

Habit stacking is brilliant. Use what you already do to help you build new, better habits. And I agree, discomfort is where growth happens. Step out of your comfort zone frequently to see those results Omar Halabieh

3 months after I left my multi-million dollar agency

I‚Äôd earned zero dollars.

Understandably, no one at the agency expected me to leave.

And when I told them I didn‚Äôt have a formed plan, they asked:

You have a family. Are you really going to leave without a plan?

But I felt called.

The plan mattered less than the mission.

So, I said:

1. I have a ton of self-belief.
2. I‚Äôm not lazy.

I saw these as good enough to figure it out.

I also knew that I was so bought into the mission of turning 6-figure chief everything officers into 7-figure calm visionary leaders.

My mission is to bring autonomy to the world.

And to do that, I need to provide immense value.

So, when people decide to make a massive change for themselves‚Ä¶

They‚Äôre confident it‚Äôs going to work.

I recorded this  before I got my first client.

The netherworld of leaving a multi-million dollar company to pursue something I‚Äôve never done before.

We‚Äôve got a few clients in now, and I feel so F‚Äôing fortunate that I listened to the call.

I didn‚Äôt play it safe. I could have.

And 99% of people around me were telling me to do so.

I share this for one reason:

Don‚Äôt be impatient with the result if you have value to give.

Don‚Äôt focus so much on what you get.

Focus on what you give.

Combine that with purpose, and you will have the most potent thing on earth.

Rooting for you.

In love and lattes,
Colby

What do Satya Nadella, Sara Blakely, and Elon Musk have in common?
They are all successful introvert founders. How many of their traits do you share?

 Do you prefer thinking before speaking?
 Do you focus deeply on what matters?
 Do you value substance over noise?

Then you already have what it takes to build something great. 

They didn‚Äôt succeed by being the loudest in the room.

They built their businesses with
- focus,
- depth, and
- strategic thinking.

And so can you.


Here‚Äôs why introverts like them make unstoppable entrepreneurs:


1Ô∏è‚É£ You build deep, meaningful relationships

Satya Nadella transformed Microsoft.

Not by force,
but by building trust.

He created a culture shift that made his team stronger.
One real connection can change everything.


2Ô∏è‚É£ You thrive in solitude

Elon Musk isn‚Äôt driven by meetings. He
‚Üí locks in,
‚Üí tunes out the noise, and
‚Üí engineers the future.

Game-changing ideas happen when you step back and let them form.


3Ô∏è‚É£ You focus deeply

Sara Blakely built Spanx by
obsessing over the details no one else saw.

Deep focus leads to breakthroughs others miss.


4Ô∏è‚É£ You lead with steady confidence

Nadella didn‚Äôt make bold, reckless moves.
He led with vision and consistency.

People follow those who stay calm under pressure.


5Ô∏è‚É£ You listen between the lines

Blakely didn‚Äôt just sell a product.
She understood what women actually wanted. 

Real success comes from hearing what others overlook.


6Ô∏è‚É£ You sell through trust, not pressure

Musk‚Äôs fans don‚Äôt buy Tesla because of flashy ads.

They buy because they believe in the mission.

People buy from those who truly understand them.


7Ô∏è‚É£ You keep things simple

The best products solve real problems without overcomplication.

A
- lean,
- focused business

moves faster and lasts longer.


8Ô∏è‚É£ You avoid unnecessary meetings

Nadella streamlined Microsoft by cutting the noise.

Real work happens in
 deep focus,
 not endless conversations.


9Ô∏è‚É£ You value impact over noise

Blakely didn‚Äôt scream for attention.
She let her product do the talking.

When you act, it moves the needle.


 You embrace constraints

Musk built Tesla with limited resources and massive obstacles.

Constraints fuel creativity when you know how to use them.


 Introversion isn‚Äôt a weakness
 It‚Äôs an advantage.

Your ability to
‚Ü≥ think deeply,
‚Ü≥ focus intensely, and
‚Ü≥ build meaningful connections

...isn‚Äôt just useful.

It‚Äôs exactly what makes a great entrepreneur.


 So stop wondering if you have what it takes.

You already do. 


‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

What‚Äôs the business idea you‚Äôve always considered?

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî


I am, and my mission is to help introverted entrepreneurs and professionals thrive as they are while protecting their energy to focus on their dreams.

postsData.content:
‚ÄúAltman‚Äôs take? AI scales like compute, costs collapse, and intelligence value goes super-exponential. Sounds great‚Äîuntil you see the cracks.

>AI agents as virtual coworkers? Sure, but who owns them? The shift isn‚Äôt just automation‚Äîit‚Äôs control over cognitive labor.
>Software engineering disrupted first? Not shocking. But if models write the code, who writes the models?
>Scientific progress accelerates? Yes, but with skewed access, breakthroughs won‚Äôt be evenly distributed.
>Cheaper goods, pricier land? Standard capital lock-in‚Äîintelligence deflates, ownership inflates.

 Economic Reality Check
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúCompute budgets‚Äù decide who gets augmented intelligence.
‚Ä¢ Labor loses pricing power unless agency shifts from AI tools to AI ownership.
‚Ä¢ Capital doesn‚Äôt get disrupted‚Äîit reconfigures to extract from AI-driven value shifts.

 The Real Risk
‚Ä¢ Intelligence gets cheap, but autonomy doesn‚Äôt.
‚Ä¢ AI as an amplifier? Yes. But of what‚Äîand for whom?
‚Ä¢ Centralized AI = intelligence as a controlled commodity, not a universal uplift.

My Final Thought: ‚ÄúUnlimited genius‚Äù sounds great, but who holds the keys? The future isn‚Äôt just about AI‚Äôs trajectory‚Äîit‚Äôs about who architects the constraints.‚Äù‚Äù

Say goodbye to urgency culture!

There‚Äôs a big difference between:

‚Ü≥ A productive work environment.
‚Ü≥ And an urgency culture‚Äîwhere everything feels like a crisis and pressure is the norm.

Here are the signs you‚Äôre trapped in urgency culture:

1/ Every task is marked ‚ÄúASAP.‚Äù

2/ Emails demand an immediate response.

3/ Working late is seen as dedication.

4/ Meetings are scheduled last minute.

5/ There‚Äôs constant pressure to multitask.

6/ Taking breaks makes you feel guilty.

7/ Deadlines are always unrealistic.

8/ Everyone‚Äôs exhausted, but no one admits it.

9/ Not being available 24/7 makes you seem unreliable.

10/ You constantly feel like you‚Äôve forgotten something.

The truth?

Speed of work ‚â† Quality of work.

‚Ü≥ You don‚Äôt have to reply to that message immediately.
‚Ü≥ You don‚Äôt have to sacrifice your break for another task.
‚Ü≥ You don‚Äôt have to live with anxiety because of others' expectations.

A high-performance culture values efficiency.

Not just constant pressure.

postsData.content:
Yann LeCun Core Argument in One Line
"Forget generative models; intelligence is just self-consistent embeddings evolving in an energy landscape."

Here‚Äôs the problem‚Äîthis isn‚Äôt a rejection of LLMs; it‚Äôs a rejection of
as a whole in favor of deterministic representation shaping.

But intelligence isn‚Äôt static embeddings; it‚Äôs thermodynamic adaptation‚Äîdiffusion through an evolving landscape, not just pre-trained compression.

His final warning? ‚ÄòIf you‚Äôre interested in human-level AI, don‚Äôt work on LLMs.‚Äô (totally agree.)

But here‚Äôs the catch: human intelligence isn‚Äôt just a stack of embeddings either.

The future isn‚Äôt throwing out generative models‚Äîit‚Äôs about guiding them beyond static constraints into adaptive, self-refining cognitive systems.

Human-level AI won‚Äôt come from compression alone. It emerges at the edge of adaptation.

comments.commentText: I think of LLMs as more like the 'stuff of thought' or the generation of conceptual material that intelligent beings typically express, such as the ability to form abstractions. However these abstractions are disembodied completely from their original source. Intelligence can arise from the arrangement of conceptual material, but the mere existence of conceptual material does not guarantee intelligence.

postsData.commentAdded: Insightful perspective! Emphasizing the role of adaptation in AI highlights the path forward. Looking forward to seeing how generative models evolve!

What most organisations wouldn't tell you, but they EXPECT IT from you ...

Build Proof, Not Just Skills.

A lot of young professionals make the mistake of thinking that taking courses and getting certifications is enough to land opportunities. While learning is great, what you really need is a PROOF OF WORK

Think about it, who would you hire?

 Someone with 5 certifications in digital marketing, OR

1Ô∏è‚É£ Start a Personal Project ‚Äì Want to be a marketer? Grow your own social media page. Want to be a writer? Start a blog. Want to be in tech? Build and showcase a mini project.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Freelance or Volunteer ‚Äì Reach out to startups or organisations and volunteer

4Ô∏è‚É£ Internships & Externships ‚Äì Real-world experience beats theory. Get hands-on experience with actual business problems.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Results Over Effort ‚Äì Don‚Äôt just say, "I worked on a project." Say, "I increased engagement by 200%." Numbers and impact matter.

This year, if you'd like to increase your chances of getting a high paying job as a young professional, then get a SOLID proof of work.

postsData.content:
Want to add 2x more productive hours tomorrow? 

Stop trying to "optimize" your sleep the wrong way.

Recent research shows just one night of poor sleep...
‚§∑ cuts memory formation by 40%
‚§∑ slashes creative problem-solving by 60%.

But here's the counterintuitive truth:

Most "sleep tips" actually make things worse.

‚Üì Here's what not to do... and what to do instead ‚Üì

 Eliminate all sounds and light from the bedroom
 Use white noise but lower it over time.
‚§∑ You want to become RESILIENT to disturbances
(not a delicate flower who wakes if a pin drops)

 Try to forget your problems
 REMEMBER them instead (write them down)
‚§∑ Otherwise your brain won't stop nudging you

 Exercise in the evening to tire yourself out
 Gentle movement (walk, stretch) 2 hours before bed
‚§∑ Evening exercise spikes cortisol when it should drop

 Try to "catch up" on weekends
 Keep the same wake time, even after bad nights
‚§∑ Your brain's clock craves consistency over quantity

 Unwind with binge watching TV
 Read escapist fiction that sends you to dreamland
‚§∑ Stress from "thrilling" shows will keep you up.

 Distract or entertain yourself with devices
 Go "full amish" for 2 hours before bed
‚§∑ Your phone is purpose built to amp up (not calm) you

 Be a work-eat-sleep machine
 Spend time daily on non-work non-growth hobbies
‚§∑ Always improving means always anxious.
(... and always anxious = bad sleep!)

The elite performers I work with all share one trait:
They chase excellence in recovery, not just in action.

Master sleep and you'll master everything else.

Ô∏è Repost to help others upgrade their Zzz's

comments.commentText: Very insightful as always. Relaxed movement in the evening works wonders for me, like a sunset walk.
Love that. Movement without intensity is the goal. Your evening routine should prioritize winding down.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely vital insights! Prioritizing sleep is a game-changer for productivity. Excited to implement these strategies! üí° #SleepSmart

postsData.content:
Predatory performance reviews. I‚Äôve been seeing them pop up a lot lately.

It‚Äôs just another weapon in the arsenal of employers to wrongly terminate employees.

These performance reviews come in all kinds of silly shapes and sizes. Where the details of the review are top notch, meeting and exceeding in every category, but assigned a below average top line ranking.

Some predatory performance review are...
 used clearly as a precursor to justify a PIP of an older worker
 based solely on biased opinions of a manager who does not like you
 intended to make you feel not valued or disrespected
 based on blatant gaslighting and provable lies
 used solely for retaliation for something you did
 used by abusive power-hungry bullies who enjoy doing it
 intended to send a message to you to start looking for a job

If you get a predatory performance review. Don‚Äôt sign it. Don‚Äôt make things easy for your manager. By signing it you agree to the lies and mischaracterizations.

Gather the evidence to show how your manager has been targeting you.
 treating you differently than others
 undermining you
 sabotaging you
 setting you up for failure

Document everything.

I‚Äôm not saying you will keep your job. The train may have already left the station, maybe not. Use it to show the targeted, abusive environment you suffered in to negotiate an exit and a better separation package.

You‚Äôd be surprised how often and how much your employer is willing to pay you to go away quietly.

comments.commentText: No one should have to tolerate gaslighting or bias like that! ‚ÄçÔ∏è You deserve better, and sometimes fighting for what's right is the best way to level up, even if it means finding a new opportunity.

postsData.commentAdded: This is a powerful reminder! Documentation is key in these situations. Standing your ground can open up opportunities for a better resolution.

postsData.content:
A laundry list of feedback kills coaching effectiveness


I recently had a great conversation with(VP of Sales at Xello). Her journey from aspiring math teacher to sales leader revealed a profound truth: The best sales coaches aren't just strong performers - they're natural teachers at heart.


One coaching insight that stood out: Stop dumping feedback on your reps!!

Jackelyn shared that the worst thing you can do is overwhelm reps with a laundry list of improvements. Instead, focus on one theme and ensure they walk away with the most impactful action item.


Sales leaders, reflect on these coaching questions:

- Are you telling reps what to fix, or asking questions that help them discover solutions?
- Do you know how each team member prefers to celebrate wins beyond just closing deals?
- When reviewing calls, do you let reps self-identify areas for improvement before sharing your observations?
- Are you tracking whether your coaching actually creates behavior change?


In the full episode, we covered:

- Why great performance doesn't automatically translate to great coaching
- The critical balance between mindset and skillset development
- How to measure coaching effectiveness through scorecards
- Building trust before diving into coaching
- Why frontline managers need more coaching than reps
- Using AI as a starting point, not the end solution


Full conversation in the comments

postsData.content:
One of my childhood dreams was to work with tigers.

In 2011, I found myself in Thailand, spending a month volunteering at a tiger temple.

It was a lifetime experience.

But when I reflected on why it meant so much to me, something surprising came to light.

Beneath my love for tigers, I discovered a deeper calling.

I wanted to save anything that has been damaged by irresponsible humans.

Tigers were one of them. They are still critically endangered.

And I was one of them too. I was hurt and broken.

The desire to find something that can heal me and make me whole became a driving force.

I did find it eventually. And so can you.

As children, we have dreams and passions that feel natural to us.

We get excited by them without overthinking.

But as we grow older, we dismiss those passions as ‚Äújust a phase‚Äù or ‚Äúnot practical.‚Äù

What if those childhood dreams are actually guiding us toward our deeper calling?

Take a moment.

Ask yourself these questions and listen to what your younger self tells you.

What did you love to do?
What made time disappear?
What brought you the most joy without effort?
How did those activities make you feel about yourself?
Find the thread. Was it creativity? Helping others?

Start exploring how that childhood passion can fit into your life today.

You might find it's still waiting for you.

---------------

 Ready to dive deeper? Take the FREE Ikigai Assessment

Do you think interviewers only judge you based on your answers? 


If yes then you are mistaken.
Interviewers notice every single thing from the time you enter till you leave.

It is not just your answers but also your non-verbal ways of communicating like body language, facial expressions and tone of voice because:

‚Üí It sets the tone for the entire interaction
‚Üí It shows honesty and sincerity building trust
‚Üí It shows your genuine interest and engagement

Here is what you can do to make a difference:

1/ A firm handshake, a warm smile, and maintaining eye contact convey confidence and professionalism, helping to establish a positive rapport.

2/ Sit upright, maintain an open posture and avoid fidgeting to project poise. This speaks about your self-assurance.

3/ Nodding, leaning forward attentively and mirroring the interviewer's gestures shows active listening and genuine interest in the conversation.

4/ Note subtle cues from your interviewer's body language. Are they leaning or displaying skepticism? Adjust your communication style accordingly.

5/ Be receptive to feedback. Flexibility and adaptability show your interpersonal skills and emotional intelligence.


Having control over your non-verbal communication will take time but these cues say a lot about your confidence and professionalism.

Your body speaks volumes, is it saying all the right things?

Do share your thoughts in the comments.

Followfor more.

postsData.content:
On turning lead into gold: 

Yesterday, I found myself in the ER with my daughter. Again.
Then sitting in the ultrasound department, waiting. Again. She's a generally healthy kid, but this one thing pops up once in a while.

I pulled up one of my favorite apps, Finch. It suggested an affirmation:

I am grateful for the present moment.

My first thought? "Well, that's poorly timed!"

Grateful to have a kid who might end the day in surgery? No. Not even a little.

But I know this much, alchemists don‚Äôt wait for gold to appear. They create it. So I decided to ask myself, how can I make this affirmation true?

So I leaned in on my gratitude and discovered that yes, there was a lot to be thankful for, even in the waiting room of the U/S department.

I'm grateful for modern medicine. For skilled, compassionate staff. And for a child who has been through this too many times, yet emerges more resilient each time.

Jung taught that transformation doesn‚Äôt come from avoiding suffering. It comes from engaging with it, shaping it, making meaning from it. So I did.

And the moment shifted.

Not into something easy. Not into something I wanted. But it became something I could bear, and even meet with strength. I found myself breathing a bit more easily.

We spent the night in the hospital, and after a second ultrasound today she's being discharged right now with, ironically, good news about her condition! We're taking the win.

Now I‚Äôm curious, have you ever turned a tough moment into something you could hold with strength? Share your story in the comments and let‚Äôs inspire each other. And if you know someone who could use this reminder, feel free to repost!

comments.commentText: Wow, what an inspiring story! Finding gratitude and strength in tough times shows how strong you are. I'm so glad to hear that your daughter is doing well now.
Camielle C. it was really stressful, and I'm glad to be home. And I am really glad that I developed the skill of reframing!

Finding that shift in perspective takes strength and patience, but it often leads to a more resilient, hopeful outlook. It‚Äôs a powerful reminder that even in trying circumstances, there is room for growth and gratitude.Malkie Rimon
Jacqueline N. Thank you

postsData.commentAdded: Thank you for sharing your journey! Its inspiring to see how gratitude can transform tough moments. Wishing you and your daughter continued strength and health!

postsData.content:
Empathetic doesn‚Äôt mean weak.

Empathetic leaders create a lasting impact.

But too often, leaders hold back, afraid empathy makes them soft.

Empathy is your superpower.

It deepens relationships and drives real impact.

Here‚Äôs how to lead with both heart and confidence:

1. Lead with understanding, not control.
‚Ü≥ Support, guide, and trust your team.
‚Ü≥ Give them room to grow, not just rules to follow.

2. Listen as it matters.
‚Ü≥ People want to feel heard, not just acknowledged.
‚Ü≥ Ask thoughtful questions and avoid interruptions.

3. Build real connections.
‚Ü≥ Leadership isn‚Äôt about power; it‚Äôs about people.
‚Ü≥ Take time to know your team beyond their tasks.

4. Ask before advising.
‚Ü≥ Instead of giving quick answers, ask: ‚ÄúWhat do you think?‚Äù
‚Ü≥ Help others develop confidence in their own decisions.

5. Create a safe space for ideas.
‚Ü≥ Fear kills creativity.
‚Ü≥ Encourage new ideas, even if they fail.

6. Protect your energy.
‚Ü≥ You can‚Äôt pour from an empty cup.
‚Ü≥ Set boundaries and model work-life balance.

7. Lead with both empathy and action.
‚Ü≥ Kindness and decisiveness can coexist.
‚Ü≥ People follow those who care and make things happen.

Your title does not make you a leader.

The way you impact your team does.

Repost to help a leader be more empathetic.
Followfor more.

comments.commentText: Empathy isn‚Äôt a weakness, it‚Äôs a leadership advantage. The best leaders balance kindness with action, trust with accountability, and support with challenge. Lead with both heart and confidence, and watch your team thrive.

Good one! Fatou Seck Mathon

Empathy strengthens leadership, it‚Äôs not a weakness.

People thrive when they feel valued and heard.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Empathy in leadership fosters trust and innovation‚Äîits the key to building strong, resilient teams. Great insights!

For most of my career, I proudly described myself as someone who preferred working for others. ‚Äúùòê‚ÄôùòÆ ùò≥ùò™ùò¥ùò¨-ùò¢ùò∑ùò¶ùò≥ùò¥ùò¶,‚Äù I‚Äôd say with conviction. But a couple of years ago, I opened the door to a new way of thinking. Instead of defining myself as risk-averse, I began saying, ‚Äúùòê‚Äôùò∑ùò¶ ùò¢ùò≠ùò∏ùò¢ùò∫ùò¥ ùò£ùò¶ùò¶ùòØ ùò≥ùò™ùò¥ùò¨-ùò¢ùò∑ùò¶ùò≥ùò¥ùò¶ ùò™ùòØ ùòµùò©ùò¶ ùò±ùò¢ùò¥ùòµ.‚Äù

That simple shift in perspective planted a seed.

Today, I‚Äôm stepping boldly into a new chapter, leaving behind Corporate America to fully embrace my purpose: to speak, write, coach, and consult. This isn‚Äôt just about a career change; it‚Äôs about living in alignment with my calling to help those who feel stuck, struggling, or irreparably damaged by trauma.

For years, I felt stuck myself‚Äîsuccessful on the outside but triggered and unsure of how to truly heal. It was through my own deep understanding of trauma‚Äîas a healthcare executive, a provider, and someone receiving care‚Äîthat I finally stepped into my resilience and began to heal. No I help others shift their narrative‚Äîfrom "ùòê ùò¢ùòÆ ùò™ùò≥ùò≥ùò¶ùò±ùò¢ùò≥ùò¢ùò£ùò≠ùò∫ ùò•ùò¢ùòÆùò¢ùò®ùò¶ùò•" to ‚Äúùòê ùò¢ùòÆ ùò≥ùò¶ùò¥ùò™ùò≠ùò™ùò¶ùòØùòµ, ùò¢ùòØùò• ùòê ùò§ùò¢ùòØ ùò©ùò¶ùò¢ùò≠.‚Äù

While working in Corporate America, I began this journey:
 Publishing my bestselling book, Resolve to Rise: Become Greater than Your Circumstances
 Launching platforms on Instagram, TikTok, and YouTube
 Designing and launching my website, Resolve to Rise
 Connecting with thousands through my blog and videos

One of the most pivotal moments came during a speaking engagement with workers‚Äô compensation adjusters. The unexpected impact of that talk confirmed what I‚Äôve known all along: my message resonates because it speaks to those who are silently struggling.

Now, I‚Äôm fully stepping into my dream, with a clear focus on reaching those impacted by chronic stress, PTSD, and Complex PTSD‚Äîand those who support them. My mission is to change the narrative from ‚ÄúI‚Äôm irreparably damaged‚Äù to ‚ÄúI am resilient, and I can heal.‚Äù

To those who feel stuck, I encourage you to take that first step toward boldness. To those supporting others in their healing journey, let‚Äôs connect. Together, we can rise and create a movement that inspires change, healing, and resilience.

This is only the beginning.

(Photography by The Jessica Martin)

The Hidden Power of Corporate Loan Syndication: What Every Business Leader Should Know?

If a company requires ‚Çπ500 crore, instead of one bank, five banks can share the risk, each contributing ‚Çπ100 crore.

Corporate loan syndication is a crucial but often overlooked strategy for financing major acquisitions, infrastructure, and expansion.

What is Corporate Loan Syndication?

Loan syndication allows multiple banks to share a large loan, reducing risk and offering substantial capital, thus crucial for business growth.

Why Do Businesses Need Loan Syndication?

As companies grow, so do their funding needs. A single-lender approach often faces:
- Regulatory lending limits restricting loan size.
- Higher interest rates due to concentrated risk.
- Liquidity concerns limiting available capital.

Syndicated loans solve these challenges by distributing the loan among multiple lenders, making them ideal for:
- Mega infrastructure projects (airports, power plants, highways).
- Real estate development (commercial buildings, mixed-use projects).
- Corporate expansions & M&A transactions.

Bilateral Loans vs. Syndicated Loans:

Bilateral Loan (Single Lender Model)
- One bank provides 100% of the loan‚Äîhigher risk, stricter terms.
- Best for smaller corporate loans or short-term financing.

Syndicated Loan (Multi-Lender Model)
- Multiple banks share the loan‚Äîreducing risk per lender.
- Larger loan amounts with flexible repayment terms.

For funding needs over ‚Çπ50 crore, syndicated lending is typically more effective.

Who Are the Key Players?

- Lead Arranger (Bookrunner): The financial institution structuring the deal and securing lenders.
- Co-Arrangers & Lenders: Banks providing capital based on agreed terms.
-Borrower (Corporation): The company seeking financing, needing strong financials.
- Loan Syndication Consultant: The advisor who ensures seamless structuring, compliance, and execution.

Effective syndication relies more on deal structuring than loan size to attract lenders.
Why Loan Syndication Matters in Today‚Äôs Economy:

As global capital markets tighten, syndicated lending gains popularity among borrowers and lenders.

For businesses, it offers:
-Access to larger funding pools.
- Competitive interest rates due to risk-sharing.
- Flexible repayment structures tailored to growth.

For lenders, it enables:
- Risk diversification across multiple banks.
-Participation in high-value deals.
-Stronger relationships with corporate borrowers.

Final Thoughts: Are You Leveraging Syndicated Lending?

Many businesses consider syndicated lending only under funding constraints.

Considering large-scale expansion? Syndicated lending might unlock flexible financing. Has your business explored this? What challenges did you encounter with large-scale funding? Share your thoughts!

postsData.content:
RFPs: A Seller‚Äôs Biggest Gamble?

Thank you Koen Stam for inspiring me in today's post :-)

Here it is ....
Most sellers hear RFP and think:
"If I wasn‚Äôt involved early, I have no chance of winning."
Not true.
Let's get real. RFPs are expensive for both buyers and sellers.
So why do companies beyond the scale-up stage still use them?
Because RFPs aren‚Äôt just about picking a solution, the market out there is so competitive and there is usually a sea of solutions and vendors, so buyers use RFP's/RFQ to have a way of getting information regarding the different vendors and evaluating them, and believe me, it is not all about what your solution is and how much it costs...

What buyers don‚Äôt write in the RFQ matters just as much as what they do:
- Is your company stable enough to fulfill a multi-year contract?
- Does your leadership team inspire confidence?
- Are you the right size and stage for the scale of what they are looking for?
- Can you show thought leadership and alignment with their vision?

And here‚Äôs another reality:
Sometimes, RFPs aren‚Äôt about winning
There are strategic reasons to participate even when the odds aren‚Äôt great:
1) Positioning your company for future opportunities
2) Learning the customer‚Äôs pain points and decision making process
3) Gaining credibility in a competitive market

But if you choose to compete, don‚Äôt just follow the process. Reshape it.
The Challenger Sales Methodology gives you an edge, even when you didn‚Äôt influence the RFP. Thats my go-to approach that has worked wonders in winning RFQ's

Here‚Äôs how Challenger sellers win:

1) They Teach
--> RFPs are written with assumptions. Your job is to challenge them.
-Are they prioritizing the wrong criteria
- Are they missing hidden risks or opportunities
- A well-placed question can reframe the conversation in your favor.
2)They Tailor
---> Most vendors copy-paste responses. Challenger sellers don‚Äôt.
- They tie their solution directly to the customer‚Äôs specific priorities
- They highlight differentiators that actually matter, not just buzzwords
3) They Take Control
---> Challenger sellers don‚Äôt wait for decisions. They shape them.
- They push back when the process is flawed
- They uncover unspoken needs with strategic questions
- They don‚Äôt play by the rules. They redefine them.

Here‚Äôs the truth.
You don‚Äôt need to influence the RFP/RFQ before it drops to win.
But you do need to influence the buyer‚Äôs thinking once you are in the process.
The best sellers don‚Äôt just answer RFPs. They rewrite the game.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! RFPs offer a unique opportunity to shape buyer perceptions and demonstrate value beyond just pricing. Love the Challenger approach!

postsData.content:
‚ÄúI want to be in the moment ‚Äî just not this moment.‚Äù

We've all been there. Stuck in a meeting, overwhelmed by deadlines, facing a difficult conversation‚Ä¶ THIS moment? No, thanks. Maybe the next one.
But here‚Äôs the thing: Presence isn‚Äôt about picking only the pleasant moments. It‚Äôs about learning to stay ‚Äî especially when discomfort makes us want to check out, scroll away, or mentally fast-forward.

From a neurological perspective, when a moment feels unbearable, our brains kick into fight, flight, or freeze mode. The amygdala sounds the alarm, stress hormones flood in, and suddenly, presence feels like the last thing we want. We escape into planning, overthinking, or outright avoidance ‚Äî not because we're weak but because our nervous system is doing its job: protecting us.

But what if we could build a different response?
Instead of needing every moment to be comfortable, what if we learned to stay with it without getting stuck in it?
 Regulate first. Deep breath. Feet on the ground. Presence starts with safety.
 Notice, don‚Äôt judge. ‚ÄúAh, my brain wants OUT. Interesting.‚Äù Observation creates space.
 Shift from escape to curiosity. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs here for me right now?‚Äù Challenge the urge to flee.
 Micro-doses of discomfort build resilience. The more we learn to sit with small discomforts (e.g. cold showers, ice baths, challenging exercising helps as well), the greater our capacity to handle the big ones

Because being in the moment isn‚Äôt about loving every second. It‚Äôs about developing the strength to stay present even when the moment is messy, awkward, or hard.

So, the next time you wish for a fast-forward button, try this: Pause, breathe, and stay just a little longer.
Because real presence isn‚Äôt about perfect moments ‚Äî it‚Äôs about showing up for the ones that matter.
Picture source: The NewYorker

What then emerges as our true greatness can no longer be described in words.

Your business is stuck because you're scared.

But here's the truth:

Fear disguises itself as logic.

No founder admits they're terrified.
No CEO confesses their doubts.
No leader shares their 3am panic.

7 hidden fears killing your growth:

1. "I'll lose control if I delegate"
‚Ü≥ Control is an illusion suffocating growth
‚Ü≥ Release one decision daily without checking

2. "Someone might do it better"
‚Ü≥ Your ego is more expensive than hiring experts
‚Ü≥ Make "replaceable" your superpower

3. "What if it all falls apart?"
‚Ü≥ Playing small feels safe but guarantees failure
‚Ü≥ Build guardrails, not roadblocks

4. "I'm not ready for the next level"
‚Ü≥ Waiting for readiness is waiting forever
‚Ü≥ Create momentum before mastery

5. "My team might outgrow me"
‚Ü≥ Your success is measured by their growth
‚Ü≥ Launch that project within 48 hours

6. "I don't deserve bigger success"
‚Ü≥ Your self-doubt limits your potential
‚Ü≥ Speak your expertise without apology

7. "What if I make the wrong choice?"
‚Ü≥ Your analysis addiction slows momentum
‚Ü≥ Set 48-hour decision deadlines

The truth:

Your fear of failing big
Is ensuring you stay small.

postsData.content:
Want more yeses and less pushy sales talk? Try these simple phrases that build trust and win more business - 100% guaranteed. 

Here‚Äôs what most people don‚Äôt realize:
Forcing a ‚Äúyes‚Äù actually pushes people away.

One-sided pitches raise suspicion, not confidence.
Trust isn‚Äôt built by you talking‚Äîit‚Äôs built by them feeling heard.
The truth?

If your prospects sense pressure, they‚Äôll tune you out. They need transparency, respect, and the space to decide for themselves. When they feel safe, trust follows naturally.

‚Äúhard sell‚Äù to ‚Äútrue connection.‚Äù
‚ÄúMy job is to make sure you have the information you need so you can make a decision.‚Äù

Sets the tone: You‚Äôre here to help, not force.
‚ÄúWould it make sense to schedule a demo so you can see how it works?‚Äù

Invites them to choose instead of pushing them into a corner.
‚ÄúHere are the benefits and drawbacks.‚Äù

No solution is perfect. Showing both sides builds credibility.
‚ÄúWhat do you think you‚Äôll do?‚Äù

Empowers them to articulate their own decision.
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your theory on why that is?‚Äù

Encourages reflection‚Äîso they feel like a partner, not a target.
‚ÄúHere‚Äôs what I know. And here‚Äôs what I don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

Admitting uncertainty makes what you do know more trustworthy.
‚ÄúWould it be helpful if I shared how others have handled this?‚Äù

Offers insights without feeling like a sales pitch.
‚ÄúIf this isn‚Äôt a fit, that‚Äôs totally fine.‚Äù

Removes pressure‚Äînobody wants to feel cornered.
‚ÄúFeel free to push back if this doesn‚Äôt make sense.‚Äù

Invites honest dialogue instead of silent objections.
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs figure this out together.‚Äù

Signals collaboration rather than a seller-vs.-buyer standoff.
‚ÄúIt sounds like you have a reason for saying that.‚Äù

Shows empathy and encourages them to expand on their concerns.
‚ÄúIt seems like you have some concerns.‚Äù

Acknowledges doubts, making them feel heard instead of judged.
‚ÄúYou‚Äôve probably considered outsourcing it.‚Äù

Assumes they‚Äôre informed, avoiding any hint of condescension.
Ready to ditch the one-size-fits-all ‚Äòclosing lines‚Äô and start building genuine trust?

The only risk is waiting too long‚Äîbecause trust is earned, not demanded. When you empower prospects to choose, they‚Äôll choose you more often.

comments.commentText: I‚Äôve been applying this to job interviews‚Äîsame principles, same results.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Building trust leads to stronger relationships. Its all about partnering with prospects, not pushing. Great insights!

Unlocking True Solutions: The Power of "5 Whys" in Problem-Solving 


As a leader, you need to value continuous improvement and getting to the root of any challenge, I‚Äôm a firm believer in the power of the "5 Whys" technique. Developed by Sakichi Toyoda as part of the Toyota Production System, this simple yet profound method will help you and your teams to identify underlying issues and implement lasting solutions ‚Äì both in business and in personal life.

It's more than just a process; it's a mindset ‚Äì a commitment to looking beyond the surface and delving into the "why" behind the problem. It can be applied in various fields, from mechanical engineering to customer care, to just a better understanding of the problems and how they can be addressed.

Here‚Äôs a story that illustrates its value (a personal favourite):
In a factory, a worker notices a drop of oil on the floor. Instead of just wiping it up, he asks:
1- Why is there oil here? (Oil leaking from a bolt.)
2- Why is only this bolt leaking oil? (Rubber gasket deteriorated.)
3- Why did the gasket fail? (It came from a different supplier.)
4- Why was a different supplier used? (Poor supplier evaluation process.)
5- Why was the evaluation process poor? (Lack of defined quality control procedures.)

Instead of a temporary fix, this simple chain of inquiry led to a systemic improvement in the company's procurement practices. It is a great reminder that we must dig deeper to solve issues.

As leaders, it‚Äôs easy to get caught up in putting out fires. The "5 Whys" technique allows us to step back, ask the tough questions, and create solutions that address core problems ‚Äì the kind of solutions that can improve efficiency, prevent future issues, and foster a culture of continuous improvement. It's about getting to the base and the beginning of each cause, and by doing so you can easily change for the better.

I'm sharing this because I value root-cause analysis and strategic problem-solving and I can‚Äôt stress that enough.

postsData.content:
Emotional Intelligence (EQ) is a game-changer for effective leadership. It helps managers build trust, navigate workplace challenges, and create a culture where people thrive.

Here are 10 key EQ skills to develop:

 1. Self-Awareness
 Why It Matters: Great leaders understand their emotions and how they impact others. Self-awareness helps you lead with authenticity and emotional control.
 How to Develop:
 Seek feedback from peers and mentors to understand your blind spots.

 2. Self-Regulation
 Why It Matters: Staying calm under pressure leads to rational decision-making and earns team trust.
 How to Develop:
 Use stress management techniques like deep breathing or meditation.

 3. Empathy
 Why It Matters: Leaders who show empathy build stronger teams and improve collaboration.
 How to Develop:
 Show genuine interest in employees' challenges, goals, and well-being.

 4. Effective Communication
 Why It Matters: Clear, thoughtful communication fosters trust and prevents misunderstandings.
 How to Develop:
 Improve both verbal and nonverbal communication (tone, body language).
 Give constructive feedback that is specific, actionable, and encouraging.

 5. Social Awareness
 Why It Matters: Understanding workplace dynamics helps managers build stronger connections.
 How to Develop:
 Observe team interactions and morale to identify patterns.
 Be mindful of employee engagement levels and act proactively.

 6. Conflict Resolution
 Why It Matters: A good leader resolves conflicts fairly, preventing tension from derailing productivity.
 How to Develop:
 Mediate disagreements by focusing on solutions, not blame.
 Separate personal emotions from professional problem-solving.

 7. Adaptability
 Why It Matters: In today‚Äôs fast-changing workplace, flexibility is key to long-term success.
 How to Develop:
 Embrace feedback and adjust to shifting team or company needs.
 Stay curious and open-minded when faced with challenges.

 8. Building Trust
 Why It Matters: Without trust, leadership falls apart. Employees need to believe in your words and actions.
 How to Develop:
 Be consistent‚Äîfollow through on promises.
 Admit mistakes and take responsibility to build credibility.

 9. Team Motivation
 Why It Matters: A motivated team is more engaged, productive, and committed.
 How to Develop:
 Celebrate team wins, both big and small.
 Align personal goals with the company‚Äôs mission to create purpose.

 10. Emotional Resilience
 Why It Matters: Leadership isn‚Äôt easy‚Äîyou need to stay focused, even when things go wrong.
 How to Develop:
 Reframe challenges as opportunities for growth.
 Build a strong support network of peers and mentors.

Which of these skills do you think is most important? Drop your thoughts below! ‚¨áÔ∏è

Ô∏è Repost to help others build stronger leadership skills.
 Followfor more career and leadership insights.

postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM ‚Äì Part 6 ‚Äì The Paradigm Shift
The release of DeepSeek, the unfulfilled AGI promises and the elusiveness of LLM use cases that produce ROI are forcing a reality check in the tech market. The RYLTI Knowledge Engineering (RKE} Paradigm is a revolutionary approach to analytics and discovery based on a combination of the latest science, innovative methodology and a patent-pending biomimetic technology.

Unlike the 70-year-old Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) paradigm which has succeeded only in scaling expenditures and hype while achieving sparse utility, RKE continues to deliver high value insights and outcomes. The primary enablers of RKE success are:
¬∑        Biomimicry ‚Äì imitating what works all around us, all the time, rather than investing in large scale random experimentation.
¬∑        Real-world Development Lab ‚Äì the innovative methods have been designed and tested as components of successful enterprise solutions.
¬∑        Realistic Target ‚Äì rather than trying to match and exceed human intelligence, of which we have limited knowledge and conflicting theories, RKE enables analytics tools that leverage human expertise together with what we do know about intelligence.

High Value Use Case Examples
a.     Complex Decision Processes
-F50 bank needed to select new technology and vendor for global implementation. The decision process required 50+ SVP & VP participants, with an estimated duration of 18 months.
-RKE Paradigm methodology and software was used by the project manager to model all the RFP requirements to the responders‚Äô documents, leading to a nearly unanimous decision in 12 weeks.
b.     Transforming Data into New Knowledge
-Leading research university and hospital looking to find genetic variants of unknown significance that could be linked to endometriosis and potentially reclassified, but there were only 18 patient samples available.
-RKE Paradigm methodology and software were used to build a digital twin ecosystem of the problem enabled discovery of previously unseen multidimensional and multiscale relationships. The results were published in the Journal of Molecular Diagnostics.
c.     Modeling Organizations as Complex, Dynamic Systems
-F50 Pharma was accountable for seven distinct domains of regulations and standards, and seven operational groups monitored changes in requirements and internal compliance.
-RKE Paradigm methodology and software were used to model the people, processes, technology, and information required as a dynamic ecosystem of organizational competency units, enabling a 70% resource reduction. The executive sponsor won the company‚Äôs highest innovation award.

There is a significant difference between the RKE Paradigm and traditional architectures, but reality has a way of imposing itself.
